p:
The calibration curves (in solvent and matrix extract) were determined using the dilute standard solution of the mixture of analytes investigated in the proposed analytical method. Calibration curves varied from 10 to 1000 ng/mL, containing seven calibration points (10, 50, 100, 200, 300, 500, 1000). To estimate if the matrix, affects the peak area of the analytes of the method significantly, therefore sensitivity, the slopes of the calibration lines obtained for plant and honeybees extract after standard addition (b matrix), and the solvent (b solvent) were divided to determine the matrix factor and the % matrix effect (ME) was calculated as indicated in Eq. 3.
3
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mathrm{\%ME}=\left(1-\frac{{\mathrm{b}}_{\mathrm{matrix}}}{{\mathrm{b}}_{\mathrm{solvent}}}\right)\times 100$$\end{document}
